body: Pretty cool. Any chance you would also work on the introduction/tutorial on advanced topics like Druid or celery or SQL Lab usage in superset. I kind of get lost in reading druid documentation and have no idea how it works in superset. Appreciate it.

@QiXuanWang yes, I'd love to develop out these docs. I'll start with Druid - I've been meaning to play around with the Druid / Superset setup recently - and tackle SQL Lab after. I'm unfamiliar with the celery configuration but it sounds like a fun learning opportunity, too.
Is the "dashboard permission" feature added to superset??

Will be waiting for this :) 
BTW, the three examples for adding new slice/dashboard is outdated too. The code structure seems got some major change so some of them are no longer within same file at all. Maybe it's too much for you but just write it here so someone else that owned those checkins could have a chance to rewrite something.

A non-related topic: I was thinking about adding one layer between get_data and actually passing to viewer. But realized that these data should be stored in SQL too. Was still struggling. Not sure if superset could do this though.
Those methods that named tzutc and tzlocal in tz work for me...

Embarassingly, I just found out that the apache proxy was set to 60 seconds timeout.
I didn't expect that this would lead to the very same behavior, as if gunicorn times out...

Closing the issue.
Looks like superset has created new "superset.db" in the path you specified. Thats why its working. Check once. Superset will create a path If path doesn't exist.

@pawan-kv The `superset_config.py` is loaded in `supersete/config.py`, so I set `CONFIG_PATH_ENV_VAR = '/usr/local/superset'` in supersete/config.py, and it works, which seems that there is no need to set PYTHONPATH, right?

noooo, this is not a good way, because i can build the source code.

in supersete/config.py, 
`from superset_config import *` 
 i can understand why the import failed when `superset_config.py` is put in PYTHONPATH?

Maybe Im not getting you quite right.

But this is how we can override "config.py" default settings:

1) create a new file "superset_config.py" in some directory say "/home/local_settings/".
   Add line:
          `SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI = 'sqlite:////home/data/superset.db'` (or any path u have write permissions to)

2) Now you can do either:
	`export PYTHONPATH=/home/local_settings/:$PYTHONPATH`
	OR
	`export SUPERSET_CONFIG_PATH=/home/local_settings/`

Thats it.
any update here
Looks like regression, we cannot use granularity selectors with 0.15.x :(
Removed tuple return value and added phase one query for druid, tested in staging for sqla/druid. PTAL @mistercrunch

@mistercrunch thanks for the review. decided to only replace line breaks for table viz for now since that is the main use case policy was needing. was going to port to pivot table too but going to leave that out for now since we don't have a use case and it's slightly more involved for pivot tables.
adding a user name is a good idea. will add!

@shkr Hi, I am trying to achieve the same thing with pyHive and have not been able to make it work. What is the URI you are using for setting up Superset data source? I am trying something like jdbc+hive://localhost:10000/, and it gives an error: "Can't load plugin: sqlalchemy.dialects:jdbc.hive". I am sure I must be missing something here.. Thanks in advance for any instructions on this.

-- update --
Looks like I had a hiveserver2 problem, I restarted it and then I was able to use this URI:
hive://user@localhost:10000/database
However I can't get what is listed on the wiki to work (jdbc+hive://), the error message is "Can't load plugin: sqlalchemy.dialects:jdbc.hive"

I have another question that is, what do you mean when you say use SparkSql as backend? I am fairly new to this, but AFAIK I can save dataframes in SparkSql to a Hive table, from which I can then create a Superset table/slice using the above connector. But is there more that I can do to make this process better? My overall goal is to be able to create tables/ slices from parquet files on HDFS.
Would there be any adverse tradeoffs if we raised the limit to say 5M or 10M instead?
Since we use shortened link now, this issue is out of scope, closing for now.

I found that I can close the controlling terminal and the gunicorn still run as a daemon.
But there is no order to stop/restart superset, have to `kill` the superset process, right? Or exist other ways?
Thanks!
U r welcome :-)

Unless I'm missing something I think there's something important missing here, somehow we need to keep track of the query number or some query id.

Here's a use case:
* user starts a query that will take 30 seconds to run
* but cancels after 5 seconds
* changes a filter to a new value, quickly
* starts a new query that takes 30 seconds to run
* callback from first query hits, results are incorporated (and should not!)
* callback from second query, results changes

Solution: keep a counter of `latestQueryNumber` in the state, increment at every query, if the id in the callback doesn't match the id in the `latestQueryNumber` in the state, do nothing with results.
What about letting your init system take care of superset?

Auth is handle by flask app builder, please refer to its documentation as it looks like you missed to import stuff :) http://flask-appbuilder.readthedocs.io/en/latest/security.html#authentication-methods

Several other sorts affected by the same issue:
Databases: backend, creator
Tables: table, database
Slices: slice, creator
Dashboards: creator

Try `AUTH_TYPE = 2`; this way no further import is needed in the config.
You may also ensure to install python-ldap or pyldap, respectively.

Turned out that we can just abort the ajax call, then it will return error with statusText 'abort', so chartUpdateSucceeded and chartUpdateFailed will never be called in the case of aborting
with the `query.abort()` this makes more sense to me. LGTM.

My example configuration was just meant to demonstrate that it would be rather useful to allow for specifying further gunicorn option to the superset runserver command.

In my eyes, a clean and very flexible approach would be a command line option for specifying a gunicorn config file.

@xrmx Thanks for pointing out that there might be incompatibilities. I was not aware of this. However, I actually don't even know a suitable approach of how to double check if the libraries are gevent safe. As corrected in my initial post, further benchmarks did _not_ confirm significant performance benefits. 
However, the gunicorn documentation [recommends asynchronous worker types](http://docs.gunicorn.org/en/latest/design.html#choosing-a-worker-type) for applications that perform outgoing requests which take an undefined amount of time. I quickly tested gevent, gthread and gaiohttp and didn't encounter any issues so far.
I'm not experienced enough to judge, if the gunicorn recommendation is applicable to superset and if an issue should be filed for at least evaluating the pros and cons.
hi @vavrusa, :wave:, thanks for this PR!

Can you describe how the time indexes/grouping work in Clickhouse so that we understand this PR? It looks like the custom code here is dealing with some non-standard-SQL constraints in that particular DB.

"Superset makes quoted (e.g. AVG("column")) metrics by default when it shouldn't, don't know why"

This quoting should be specified in your SQLAlchemy dialect

@ascott hi 👋, I've addressed your comments

@mistercrunch:

> Can you describe how the time indexes/grouping work in Clickhouse?

The most common table type [MergeTree](https://clickhouse.yandex/reference_en.html#MergeTree) requires segmentation by `Date` (number of days since epoch), but allows you to add other columns, like `DateTime` for seconds. These columns are however independent, so constraining query like `datetime  > now() - 3600` doesn't automatically infer that column `date` is either today or yesterday, so you have to place constraints on both columns like `datetime > now() - 3600 AND date = today()`.
Superset by default selects only main dttm column and places constraint on it, so if `datetime` is the main column, it will still inspect all parts segmented by `date` searching for `datetime`, instead of skipping parts where `date BETWEEN toDate(constraint) AND toDate(constraint)`. Does that make sense?

> This quoting should be specified in your SQLAlchemy dialect

Indeed, that's fixed in 617ea1153e34a1d6cc3b609dfc162748127c02f2

OMG thanks for fixing this! I spent a few cycles on it and didn't get to the bottom of it.
LGTM

Should we ignore this warning should, or set a CACHE_TYPE for Flask-Cache?
Isn't the reloader something we want in debug mode?
I think it's fine to not have a cache backend configured by default.
Alright... just feel not good when i saw the `ExtDeprecationWarning.`
Should we add `warnings.simplefilter('ignore', ExtDeprecationWarning)` to ignore it?
R u sure? I thought closing reloader function will be better in Debug Mode, just like disable gunicorn when we debug some.
The deprecation warnings are not coming from superset code (and they are unrelated to superset setting a cache or not), a new release of flask app builder will be released hopefully :)
Yep, i also think so.

I'm fine turning off these warnings. They're coming from the libs we use and therefore they need to fix those. Since our deps are pinned it shouldn't be an issue.

I've written a simple systemd service:
```
[Unit]
Description=Visualization platform by Airbnb

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/superset runserver -p 8088 -t 300
```
